newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish shares hit record high, led by banks.
newsitem.headline: Swedish shares hit record high, led by banks.

text.p: Sweden's stockmarket closed at a record high on Thursday, buoyed by a strong bank sector sector, low Swedish inflation data and U.S. gains.
The Stockholm general index rose 0.79 percent to 2,032.20 after shares worth 4.8 billion crowns changed owners.
The bank sector was the strongest sector, rising 2.30 percent. Nordbanken was the star performer rising seven crowns to 156 crowns after announcing a five billion crown share buy back on Wednesday.
Handelsbanken rose 6.50 to 149 crowns and Swedbank closed 1.50 crowns higher at 88 crowns.

Blue-chip Ericsson closed four crowns higher at 163, despite Motorola's heavy losses overnight in the wake of a warning about its third quarter earnings. "Motorola's development differs from Ericsson's," said an analyst.
Another winner was car safety equipment maker Autoliv, which jumped nine crowns to 236.50 on news it was selling side air bags to Volkswagen.
"It also shows the penetration of side airbags into the car market is greater than previously expected and could move onto other models," Swedbank analyst Mats Liss said.
